publicationStmt.publisher: The Characters that shaped the Silk Road - A Database and Digital Paleography of Tarim

seg.seg: ... From there on they begin to recite the laws beginning with giving, moral behaviour and meditation.
... But he had a son [and] so was attached with pride. [With] brandy, in dancing [and] play [and] somedbody else's wives and so on ... [he spent his time] ...
... the son of ..., committing negligences in this way, did not act according to the word of his parents. Then king ...
... they ... him, made on his atāne (?) and threw him into prison. || ... of the householder ...
... and ... the the prince of the throne. || Thereupon ...
... by entering and so on, all property ...
... who was prince ..., he is now ...
... in twelve years ... with the mind ... afterwards [he] went (?) ...
... he was repentant [and] became zealous in giving. ... all evils ...
... zeigte Reue [und] war eifrig im Gabe[geben].
... showed remorse [and] was diligent in [giving] gifts.
... he is redeemed from [his] sorrows. Giving gift[s] in such a way, a being (may ward off ?) evil through the power of giving.
... love arises for him. He remembers all beings. Through his desire for their good he gives gift[s].
... in the ... part the second division has ended. || This division has written Śtweruṃ –. ||

p.note: This seems to be an abbreviated story as found e.g. in the Udl. Not a real jātaka.
According to 192 "[w]ritten in medium ductus, and very clearly preserved it is the right and greater portion of a large eight line manuscript". 191 also identifies this fragment as folios 15-16.

This seems to be an abbreviated story as found e.g. in the Udl. Not a real jātaka.

According to [[Broomhead I]]: 192 "[w]ritten in medium ductus, and very clearly preserved it is the right and greater portion of a large eight line manuscript". [[Broomhead I]]: 191 also identifies this fragment as folios 15-16.

Translations from [[Schmidt KT 1974]]
Lines Translation Pages
b5 ... zeigte Reue [und] war eifrig im Gabe[geben]. 339


[[Broomhead I]]: 192 translates:

a2 From there on they befin to recite the laws beginning with the śīla, giving and meditation.

a3 He, however, had a son, such that he was fettered by pride. With brandy, in gaming and dancing with the wives of others and so on [he spent his time].

a4 The son of ..., who was so occupied with this kind of foolishness, did not behave according to the words of his father [and] mother. Thereupon [the king] ...

a5 They made away with him thence, and [they] threw him into prison. This ... of the house-holder ...

a6 and the ... of the throne. The prince thereupon ...

a7 By entering (the order of monks) and so on all property ...

a8 ... in crime.

b2 He who was ... [at that time] he [is now] ...:

b3 He will be evil. Therefore all ...

b4 ... in twelve years ... that with the mind ... and afterwards [he] went ...

b5 He was repentant and became zealous in giving ... ... and all evil deeds [left him].

b6 [He who ...] will be liberated from the hells [and] a being who gives gifts in such a way [can] by means of the power of giving [escape] evil.

b7 Friendship is born in him [and] he remembers all teh ebings. Through [his] desire for their salvation he gives gifts.

b8 ... In the ... part the second act is at an end. Śtweru[ṃ] wrote this act.

a1 ... a2 ... From there on they begin to recite the laws beginning with giving, moral behaviour and meditation. a3 ... But he had a son [and] so was attached with pride. [With] brandy, in dancing [and] play [and] somedbody else's wives and so on ... [he spent his time] ... a4 ... the son of ..., committing negligences in this way, did not act according to the word of his parents. Then king ... a5 ... they ... him, made on his atāne (?) and threw him into prison. || ... of the householder ... a6 ... and ... the the prince of the throne. || Thereupon ... a7 ... by entering and so on, all property ... a8 ... in offence ... b1 ... b2 ... who was prince ..., he is now ... b3 ... will be bad. Thereupon all ... b4 ... in twelve years ... with the mind ... afterwards [he] went (?) ... b5 ... he was repentant [and] became zealous in giving. ... all evils ... b6 ... he is redeemed from [his] sorrows. Giving gift[s] in such a way, a being (may ward off ?) evil through the power of giving. b7 ... love arises for him. He remembers all beings. Through his desire for their good he gives gift[s]. b8 ... in the ... part the second division has ended. || This division has written Śtweruṃ –. ||

[[IDP]]: IOL Toch 12.

Edition: [[Peyrot 2007]]: №12, [[Broomhead I]]: 191-192.

Complete translation: [[Broomhead I]]: 192.

Translation: a2 [[Thomas 1954]]: 718; a5 [[Carling 2000]]: 72, 165; b2 [[Thomas 1957]]: 228; b4 [[Thomas 1957]]: 208; b5 [[Schmidt KT 1974]]: 339; b8 [[Thomas 1957]]: 157, 211.

.

div.p: <citedRange>192</citedRange></bibl> translates: </p><p>a2 From there on they befin to recite the laws beginning with the śīla, giving and meditation. </p><p>a3 He, however, had a son, such that he was fettered by pride. With brandy, in gaming and dancing with the wives of others and so on [he spent his time]. </p><p>a4 The son of ..., who was so occupied with this kind of foolishness, did not behave according to the words of his father [and] mother. Thereupon [the king] ... </p><p>a5 They made away with him thence, and [they] threw him into prison. This ... of the house-holder ... </p><p>a6 and the ... of the throne. The prince thereupon ... </p><p>a7 By entering (the order of monks) and so on all property ... </p><p>a8 ... in crime. </p><p>b2 He who was ... [at that time] he [is now] ...: </p><p>b3 He will be evil. Therefore all ... </p><p>b4 ... in twelve years ... that with the mind ... and afterwards [he] went ... </p><p>b5 He was repentant and became zealous in giving ... ... and all evil deeds [left him]. </p><p>b6 [He who ...] will be liberated from the hells [and] a being who gives gifts in such a way [can] by means of the power of giving [escape] evil. </p><p>b7 Friendship is born in him [and] he remembers all teh ebings. Through [his] desire for their salvation he gives gifts. </p><p>b8 ... In the ... part the second act is at an end. Śtweru[ṃ] wrote this act. </p></project_comment>
